title: Dibamus bogadeki
text:
Dibamus bogadeki, or Bogadek's burrowing lizard (<a href="Traditional%20Chinese%20characters">Chinese</a>: 鮑氏雙足蜥), is a <a href="species">species</a> of legless <a href="lizard">lizard</a> in the <a href="Family%20%28biology%29">family</a> <a href="Dibamidae">Dibamidae</a>. The species is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>.
Etymology.
"D. bogadeki" is named after its first collector, Father Anthony Bogadek, a <a href="Herpetology">herpetologist</a> and teacher at the <a href="St.%20Louis%20School%2C%20Hong%20Kong">St Louis School</a> in Hong Kong, and a coauthor of the first major guide to Hong Kong Amphibians and Reptiles.
Distribution and ecology.
The species "D. bogadeki" can only be found on <a href="Hei%20Ling%20Chau">Hei Ling Chau</a>, <a href="Shek%20Kwu%20Chau">Shek Kwu Chau</a> and <a href="Sunshine%20Island%2C%20Hong%20Kong">Sunshine Island</a> in <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>. Discovered in 1987 on the island of <a href="Hei%20Ling%20Chau">Hei Ling Chau</a>, the species is also the only legless lizard that can be found in Hong Kong. It lives in soil or under stones or rotting wood lying on the forest floor. The first live specimen was discovered hiding under a mass of dead leaves and soil in a drain beside woodland. As a nocturnal and burrowing species it is practically blind, and its eyes are covered by scales.
Reproduction.
"D. bogadeki" is <a href="Oviparity">oviparous</a>.
